NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>f</mi> </math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>x</mi> </math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>f</mi> <mpadded> <mo>(</mo> <mpadded> <mi>x</mi> </mpadded> <mo>)</mo> </mpadded> </math> is a real number.

Let <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="f of x equals, 4 times e raised to the negative 2 x power" overflow="scroll"> <mi>f</mi> <mpadded> <mo>(</mo> <mpadded> <mi>x</mi> </mpadded> <mo>)</mo> <mo>=</mo> <mn>4</mn> <msup> <mi>e</mi> <mpadded> <mo>-</mo> <mn>2</mn> <mi>x</mi> </mpadded> </msup> </mpadded> </math>. Let <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> be the region in the first quadrant bounded by the graph of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"> <mi>f</mi> </math>, the horizontal line <math alttext="y equals 4" overflow="scroll"> <mi>y</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>4</mn> </math>, and the vertical line <math alttext="x equals 1" overflow="scroll"> <mi>x</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>1</mn> </math>. Let <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll"> <mi>S</mi> </math> be the region in the first quadrant bounded by the graph of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math>, the coordinate axes, and the vertical line <math alttext="x equals 1" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math>. Regions <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"> <mi>R</mi> </math> and <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll"> <mi>S</mi> </math> are shown in the figure.

(a) Find the area of region <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"> <mi>R</mi> </math>.

NO CALCULATOR IS ALLOWED FOR THIS QUESTION.

Show all of your work, even though the question may not explicitly remind you to do so. Clearly label any functions, graphs, tables, or other objects that you use. Justifications require that you give mathematical reasons, and that you verify the needed conditions under which relevant theorems, properties, definitions, or tests are applied. Your work will be scored on the correctness and completeness of your methods as well as your answers. Answers without supporting work will usually not receive credit.

Unless otherwise specified, answers (numeric or algebraic) need not be simplified. If your answer is given as a decimal approximation, it should be correct to three places after the decimal point.

Unless otherwise specified, the domain of a function <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>f</mi> </math> is assumed to be the set of all real numbers <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>x</mi> </math> for which <math alttext="f of x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>f</mi> <mpadded> <mo>(</mo> <mpadded> <mi>x</mi> </mpadded> <mo>)</mo> </mpadded> </math> is a real number.

Let <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math> be the function defined by <math alttext="f of x equals, 4 times e raised to the negative 2 x power" overflow="scroll"> <mi>f</mi> <mpadded> <mo>(</mo> <mpadded> <mi>x</mi> </mpadded> <mo>)</mo> <mo>=</mo> <mn>4</mn> <msup> <mi>e</mi> <mpadded> <mo>-</mo> <mn>2</mn> <mi>x</mi> </mpadded> </msup> </mpadded> </math>. Let <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> be the region in the first quadrant bounded by the graph of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"> <mi>f</mi> </math>, the horizontal line <math alttext="y equals 4" overflow="scroll"> <mi>y</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>4</mn> </math>, and the vertical line <math alttext="x equals 1" overflow="scroll"> <mi>x</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>1</mn> </math>. Let <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll"> <mi>S</mi> </math> be the region in the first quadrant bounded by the graph of <math alttext="f" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math>, the coordinate axes, and the vertical line <math alttext="x equals 1" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math>. Regions <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"> <mi>R</mi> </math> and <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll"> <mi>S</mi> </math> are shown in the figure.

(a) Find the area of region <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"> <mi>R</mi> </math>.

(b) Region <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll"> <mi>S</mi> </math> is the base of a solid. For this solid, at each <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"> <mi>x</mi> </math> the cross section perpendicular to the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"> <mi>x</mi> </math>-axis is a rectangle with area <math alttext="3 x times, f of x" overflow="scroll"> <mn>3</mn> <mi>x</mi> <mo>Â·</mo> <mi>f</mi> <mpadded> <mo>(</mo> <mpadded> <mi>x</mi> </mpadded> <mo>)</mo> </mpadded> </math>. Find the volume of the solid.
(c) Write, but do not evaluate, an expression involving an integral that gives the perimeter of region <math alttext="S" overflow="scroll"> <mi>S</mi> </math>.

topic.text: 6.11: (BC ONLY) Integrating Using Integration by Parts

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate mathematical rule or procedure based on the relationship between concepts (e.g., rate of change and accumulation) or processes (e.g., differentiation and its inverse process, anti-differentiation) to solve problems.
